Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing latest Pleistocene and Holocene glacial chronologies in the western United States with cosmogenic-nuclide and radiocarbon dating and models
Award.AbstractNarration:
Small alpine glaciers are sensitive to climate, and projections of future global warming indicate that many alpine glaciers throughout the world will shrink considerably, if not disappear altogether. This award will address two fundamental questions relevant to understanding the history and controls of alpine glaciation in the western U.S.: (1) What is the age of moraines deposited by glaciers that occur immediately downstream to those deposited during the Little Ice Age ~300 years ago? (2) How have changes in large-scale controls of climate through the last ~10,000 years (Holocene) affected glacier fluctuations? Methods to be employed to accomplish these goals will involve systematically dating cirque-glacier moraines throughout the western U.S. using in-situ cosmogenic radionuclides and radiocarbon techniques. A hierarchical climate and glacier modeling strategy will be employed to evaluate the effects of changing large-scale climate controls through the Holocene (ice sheets, insolation, greenhouse gases) on glacier mass balance and resulting fluctuations. This research strategy provides an outstanding approach to applying the geologic record to constrain the sensitivity of alpine glaciers to radiative forcing.

Broader Impact. Understanding the sensitivity of alpine glaciers to radiative forcing is of great interest with regard to landscape appearance, slope stability, water resources, sediment loading to rivers, and ecosystem health. The modeling approaches developed here will be applicable (outside of this project) to improve assessments of future anthropogenic impacts on alpine glaciation, with implications for sea-level, water resources, and societal concerns over the aesthetic qualities of glaciers. This study includes a strong element of inter-agency cooperation, with contributions for modeling supported by the USGS. This proposal will directly contribute to human resources by including the training, education, and research contributions of one Ph.D. student, with strong cross-training in elements of data acquisition, data analysis, and modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two fundamental questions relevant to understanding the history and controls of alpine glaciation in the western United States were posed in this research proposal: 1) What is the age of moraines that occur immediately distal to those deposited during the Little Ice Age?  2) How have changes in large-scale controls of climate through the Holocene affected glacier fluctuations?

     The larger part of this collaborative grant and supplement to Oregon State University (OSU) and Bentley University supported 10Be exposure dating of moraine boulders, which was completed by Shaun Marcott for his PhD dissertation at OSU in 2011. Many cirques in western North America exhibit two sets of moraines: 1) inner moraines that date to the Little Ice Age of the last few centuries, and 2) outer moraines that some believe date from the early to the late Holocene. We sampled outer cirque moraines from 13 different sites in the western U.S. and one site in southwestern Canada. At many sites two or more outer cirque moraines were sampled. In all cases, we sampled at least five boulders from each moraine. We have now dated 124 samples from moraine boulders using 10Be at the PRIME Lab, Purdue University. Our 10Be data set is one of the largest ever generated, and represents the most comprehensive coverage of cirque glaciation in the western U.S. The 10Be analyses indicate that nearly all outer cirque moraines date to the late Pleistocene or earliest Holocene, rather than the early to late Holocene as many previously believed. Thus, the Little Ice Age moraines are the only moraines in cirques that formed during all but the earliest part of the Holocene, which requires a revised interpretation of Holocene glacial activity in western North America and the associated climate forcing.

     A much smaller part of this collaborative grant funded field and laboratory expenses to obtain and analyze lake sediment cores from two strategic sites impounded by cirque moraines in the Colorado Front Range dated with 10Be exposure ages. Lake sediment cores provide a more continuous record of sediment proxies for possible glacial activity in cirques during the Holocene than do moraines, but also will provide minimum-limiting basal 14C ages for comparison with the 10Be moraine exposure ages. One of the two target sites for lake sediment coring is Caribou Lake, which is enclosed by the type Satanta Peak moraine on the west side of the Continental Divide near Arapaho Pass, where we recovered a 391-cm long sediment core. Previous 14C ages on the type Satanta Peak moraine are ambiguous because the sample material was derived from outside the moraine. Five 10Be exposure ages for moraine boulders are still in progress. Loss-on-ignition (LOI) analyses, a proxy for lake productivity, terrestrial vegetation, and glacier activity in alpine basins, were performed at 0.5 cm intervals at Bentley University and exhibit an abrupt lowering of values over a 30-cm interval low in the core. We hypothesize that the low LOI interval may be a clastic flux signal driven by renewal of glacier ice in the upper part of the cirque during the Younger Dryas cool interval, about 12,900 to 11,600 years ago, at the end of the Pleistocene. Thus, the type Satanta Peak moraine may be pre-Younger Dryas in age. Samples from the basal part of the Caribou Lake sediment core are being screened for macrofossils that will be submitted to the University of Arizona for 14C dating. Grain size analyses on the sediment core using a Beckman-Coulter instrument also are planned.
